text: When I started to playing Fallout 3 I did the same thing then once when I replayed it few years later I didn't listen to any station and that's when I heard the ambient music and I remember going: "Woah, this game has ambient music? Damn it's good"
author: Awemiss

text: I've always liked the ambient music in Bethesda's open world games like Fallout and the Elder Scrolls. It really adds something special to something as rudimentary as walking around.
author: Patrick Kruse

text: Ah yes, the best exploration song in the game.

author: Bengon

text: Yeah, if it's going to basically be the same game but shinier and in a somewhat different setting (seriously, what is Bethesda's fixation with the eastern United States?) I don't think it will be worth more than a free torrent. I'd rather not support them, although in a broad sense it won't matter. They will make a killing and it will be lauded as the newest best game ever made (of the year or month) no matter what it's like.
author: Yakumo Chen

text: +Yakumo Chen the game looks to be a massive world that they will have (hopefully) filled with more fleshed out npcs.  and Bethesda is based out of Maryland, so they like to be in their neck of the woods
author: jasondm300

text: +Yakumo Chen I believe is better to see the other areas of the US affected in the Fallout series other than the West coast. I give Bethesda props to that, exploring more that just California,  bits of Oregon and the newly introduced Nevada.
author: Pancho Lopez

text: I'm really excited for Fallout 4, returning to the post-apocalyptic setting and getting lost into it is something I'm looking forward to. I haven't delved too much in big open world games during the past few years due to time constraints, preferring to play more shorter games than a few long ones, but I feel like I'm due for one now. If I like it enough, I can see myself playing it until the year ends. We'll see!
